For a monoid $M$ and elements $a_{1}, \ldots, a_{n} \in M$, the product is defined as $\prod_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} := a_{1} \cdot \ldots \cdot a_{n}$. A special bracketing on the right-hand side is not necessary due to the associative nature of the law of composition.
A finite group G is called a p-group if the order of G is a power of p, where p is a prime number.
Does the concept of a/an Product Notation in Monoids need to be defined for a definition of a/an p-group to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The definition of a p-group focuses on the order of the group being a power of a prime number. It does not require any specific notation or method for combining elements of the group, such as the product notation in monoids. The concept of a p-group is concerned with the structure and properties of the group related to its order, not the specific operations within the group.

The product notation in monoids is a way to express the operation of combining multiple elements in a monoid, which is an associative algebraic structure with an identity element. While groups are a type of monoid, the definition of a p-group does not depend on how the elements are combined or expressed; it solely depends on the number of elements in the group (its order) being a power of a prime number.

Therefore, the concept of product notation in monoids is not necessary for the definition of a p-group to make sense. The definition of a p-group can be fully understood and applied without reference to the specific method of element combination provided by product notation in monoids.
